no encryption header then you're going to select server side encryption with s3 manage keys for encryption at rest or
you can select SN see kms are a key management service for access level encryption and we will
automatically encrypt those objects for you there's no charge for these these features any of these that I mentioned

other customers have compliance requirements or business requirements where they want to store data X number

there one is the ability kms has generally been a regional based service so we've added kms support so that we
can basically copy the kms key from one region to another region allowing you to extend cross region replication to kms
encrypted objects and then the the second thing that we added in November on the November 6 launch was ownership
over write so if you are concerned about accidental or malicious deletions of
data you can cross region replicate objects to another region and you can change the ownership
that object to a different owner thereby making it difficult or impossible for somebody to delete objects in two
separate regions so and also very easy to set up from the s3 console for that
customers use cross region replication in many ways some might just do s3
standard s very standard very typical would be s3 standard in one region and
then I'm intending to not access the data in my secondary region so you might do standard infrequent access there and

three digit or a four digit hash in your object names to create some randomness
so a couple people are saying yeah I know what you're talking about so for most of you out there not all of you but
for most of you you don't have to worry about that anymore I'm not gonna tell you exactly who should and who shouldn't but generally speaking
we've done a lot of changes behind the scenes first of all we've increased our transaction processing from about 100
per second to a thousand and a lot of people say we you said you handle millions of transactions so the the
1,000 per second is per what we call partition so a partition is an internal
term that can be a bucket can be a partition or each of your prefixes in a bucket can be a partition or we can
further partition your prefixes into a hundred different partitions and each
partition can handle a thousand transactions per second so we get scale by going horizontal on s3 and
parallelizing a lot of the activities and actions so in addition to having about a an order of magnitude
performance improvement in our partitioning we've also automated all of that partitioning behind the scenes so
most of you don't have to do anything we're gonna see increases in traffic within your buckets and within your
prefixes and we're gonna automatically partition for you on the back end and it's generally taking maybe about an
hour so if you're seeing a lot of increased traffic and you're seeing a
little bit slower performance and if it doesn't resolve itself in an hour maybe an hour and a half then you might want
to open a ticket but generally speaking you won't have to do anything to do that and then for any of you if you're I
don't know a game producer or something like that and you've got a new game launching and you don't want to wait an
hour or two for us to automatically partition to improve your performance you can always open a ticket ideally you
give us a weeks notice but a few days would be good tell us about the bucket tell us about your partitions tell us what day and time your launch is and and
we can pre partition your buckets for you ahead of kind of a step function
kind of an event like a launch so keep that in mind so generally speaking most
customers shouldn't need to to deal with this anymore if you want to be ultra safe the the best practice has always
been introducing a random three digit or four digit hash a character earlier on
in your key naming but again just to be clear if you don't do that we have the
ability to automatically partition no matter what your naming structure is anymore that wasn't really the case you

if you did want to do a hash again the earlier in the naming structure of the
better and this gives us the ability to if you have a four digit hash I think
that's 10,000 so we could have 10,000 partitions just on that one naming structure times a thousand transactions

be automated for most of you shouldn't have to worry about it if you do have the ability and want the best practices

percent of your data for fixity checking a few times a year and if we find any

is what is the difference between high availability and disaster recovery when you look at high availability the way we
define high availability is it is the ability to run services across different
zones in the same region such that if one zone goes down your service is still
up and running without any interruption the way we define disaster recovery is
that you are running your application in a primary region and if this act of God
or that any man-made disaster for example in hurricane sandy in that case
several data centers in New York City were flooded and were out for several
days so if you have a that kind of disaster you should be able to restore your application in a different geo
region which is at least separated by 250 miles and that is what disaster
recovery is all about so in our case the
when you're talking about disaster recovery before I go there the interesting thing to note is that s3 is
already highly available other than s3 all the other services that we run we make sure that we are running in a a
mode for our own internal services if
you look at disaster recovery there are different approaches to disaster recovery and there are pros and cons of those approaches so the first one is
what we call active passive or also known as hot and cold in that case you
run your infrastructure in one region you make the copy of your data in a different region and you keep that in
sync and when disaster happens you restore using the archival data the plus
of this approach is that is very cost efficient the downside of this approach is that there is always a lag between the data
in the primary region and the DR region so whenever dr happens you end up losing some data the second approach is hot and
warm which is active passive in this approach you are running infrastructure
in one region then you are also running infrastructure in a different region but the infrastructure in the other region
is on standby so it's in sync fully and when disaster happens you switch to their standby infrastructure this
approach works well because it does not lose you don't lose much data then also
you can switch very quickly the downside of this approach is that you are running
redundant infrastructure in two different region and it's cost prohibitive the third approaches which is hot and
hot or active active and this approach you are running your infrastructure
instead of across zones similarly you're running it across different geo regions and both infrastructure in different
regions active and taking and using customers so in this case if one region
goes down your application can work seamlessly because it's processing the requests from the other region this is a
great solution and an ideal solution the challenge and implementing this kind of
solution is that when you're implementing disaster recovery your data centers are further apart in distance so
there is latency and if you have very right heavy application it's very difficult to run them at a long distance
so in a sprinkler for disaster recovery
there are two most important sls that we rely on and that's what we commit to our
customers one is the recovery point objective which is RPO recovery point
objective means that if the dr happens and you restore your application in a different region how old is your data from the when
you're restoring it the we typically commit to 24 hours of our Pio
the second thing is recovery time objective in recovery time objective the
point here is that when you declared dr from the time they declared ER to the
time you restore your application how long it takes you to bring everything back up in our case it varies from
customers from 6 hours to 24 hours typically when we are doing dr we are aiming for four hours of RTO we use two

different services and all each of these services have unique configuration and code so when you try to implement a

region quickly then transferring it to a different region and trying to keep it
in sync and third having the automation to be able to restore everything up
